results.byline: By Kate Conger, Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu
results.title: Two Weeks of Chaos: Inside Elon Musk’s Takeover of Twitter
results.abstract: Mr. Musk ordered immediate layoffs, fired executives by email and laid down product deadlines, transforming the company.

media.copyright: Ben Jones

results.adx_keywords: Midterm Elections (2022);Elections, Senate;Elections, Governors;Elections, Attorneys General;United States Politics and Government;Lake, Kari A;Masters, Blake (1986- );Kelly, Mark E (1964- );Hobbs, Kathleen M;Finchem, Mark W;Hamadeh, Abraham;Democratic Party;Republican Party;Arizona
results.byline: By Jazmine Ulloa and Jack Healy
results.title: Arizona’s Top Races Near the Finish in a Tension-Filled Battleground
results.abstract: Senator Mark Kelly, a Democrat, holds an edge in his bid for re-election, but the race for governor appears to be a true tossup, even as several Republican candidates sow doubts about the results.

media.caption: Ballots being processed this week at the Maricopa County Elections Center in Phoenix. All four of the state’s top races were uncalled as of midday Friday.
media.copyright: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Immigration and Emigration;United States Politics and Government;Magnus, Chris (1960- );Mayorkas, Alejandro;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Customs and Border Protection (US);Homeland Security Department
results.title: Top Border Official Says He Was Asked to Resign
results.abstract: The Customs and Border Protection commissioner, Chris Magnus, has refused to step down, exposing conflicts at the Homeland Security Department over how to manage a high number of illegal border crossings.

media.caption: Chris Magnus oversees much of the customs and trade policy, as well as the country’s borders.
media.copyright: Al Drago for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Virtual Currency;Bankruptcies;Appointments and Executive Changes;Bankman-Fried, Sam;HK FTX Trading Ltd (Futures Exchange);Binance;Securities and Exchange Commission
results.title: Embattled Crypto Exchange FTX Files for Bankruptcy
results.abstract: The announcement capped a stunning week that has shocked the crypto industry.

media.caption: Sam Bankman-Fried, FTX’s founder, resigned on Friday. A corporate turnaround specialist who helped run Enron after its collapse has taken his place.
media.copyright: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Television;Comedy and Humor;internal-sub-only
results.title: Seth Meyers Is Thrilled by G.O.P.’s New Treatment of Trump
results.abstract: “Republicans are running away from Trump faster than Josh Hawley on Jan. 6,” Meyers joked on Thursday.

media.caption: Seth Meyers joked that seeing Fox News turn on Trump is like watching “‘Alien vs. Predator,’ or ‘Godzilla vs. Kong,’ or Biden vs. stairs.”
media.copyright: NBC

results.abstract: In his first communications with Twitter’s staff, the company’s new owner painted a bleak picture as more executives resigned.

results.title: Gallagher, Watermelon-Smashing Comedian, Is Dead at 76
results.abstract: He called himself “The Wizard of Odd” for his outrageous stage act, making him one of the most recognizable comedians of the 1980s.

media.caption: Gallagher in 1985. He said it was his job to “yell at the world.”
media.copyright: Gary Null/NBC, via Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Midterm Elections (2022);Elections, Senate;Masters, Blake (1986- );Kelly, Mark E (1964- );Senate;Arizona
results.title: Mark Kelly Wins Arizona Senate Race, Putting Democrats a Seat From Control
results.abstract: Mr. Kelly, who ran as a bipartisan legislator devoted to the needs of Arizona, defeated Blake Masters, a Republican newcomer whose ideological fervor failed to win over enough independent voters.

media.caption: Senator Mark Kelly was long seen as one of his party’s most vulnerable incumbents, but he prevailed over Blake Masters, a Republican running for office for the first time.
media.copyright: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Elections, House of Representatives;Content Type: Personal Profile;Redistricting and Reapportionment;Midterm Elections (2022);United States Politics and Government;Maloney, Sean Patrick;Democratic Party;Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee;New York State
results.title: Sean Patrick Maloney on His Loss, the Media and A.O.C.
results.abstract: Mr. Maloney said that he and other New York Democrats were unable to overcome suburban fears of crime. He also had some harsh words for Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

media.caption: Representative Sean Patrick Maloney said that Gov. Kathy Hochul's struggles in the suburbs hurt Democratic candidates in those areas.
media.copyright: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Midterm Elections (2022);Politics and Government;United States Politics and Government;Elections, Governors;Abrams, Stacey Y;Kemp, Brian P;Democratic Party;Georgia;Atlanta (Ga)
results.byline: By Maya King and Reid J. Epstein
results.title: Eager to Grab National Spotlight, Abrams Falls Again on Georgia Stage
results.abstract: In her second bid for governor, Stacey Abrams was dogged by complaints that she was distracted by her national ambitions and disconnected from voters at home.

media.caption: Stacey Abrams conceded to Brian Kemp on Tuesday, after raising and spending tens of millions of dollars on her second run for governor.
media.copyright: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

results.title: ‘How Did This Man Think He Had the Right to Adopt This Baby?’
results.abstract: Army Rangers killed her parents. A Marine is raising her in America. But her Afghan family says she was taken under false pretenses.

results.byline: By Emma Bubola and Henrik Pryser Libell
results.title: Norwegian Princess Engaged to a Shaman Gives Up Her Royal Duties
results.abstract: Princess Martha Louise’s belief in the supernatural has long been the subject of media fascination in Norway, but a focus on her healer fiancé proved too much.

media.caption: Princess Martha Louise of Norway and her fiancé, Durek Verrett, in Oslo, in June.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Pop and Rock Music;Parker, Mimi (1967-2022);Sparhawk, Alan;Sub Pop Records;Low (Music Group)
results.title: Mimi Parker, Moody Alt-Rock Vocalist, Is Dead at 55
results.abstract: Her influential band, Low, emerged in the 1990s, but its minimalist sound stood in sharp contrast to the anthems of angst that came to define the grunge era.

media.caption: Mimi Parker of Low in performance in Paris in 2011. The band, which she founded with her husband, Alan Sparhawk, remained an influential and acclaimed act for nearly 30 years.
media.copyright: Samuel Dietz/Redferns

results.title: A Verifiable Mess: Twitter Users Create Havoc by Impersonating Brands
results.abstract: The social media service, which is undergoing changes from its new owner Elon Musk, has descended into a messy swirl of spoof messages and parody accounts.

results.title: KFC Apologizes for Linking Chicken Promotion to Kristallnacht
results.abstract: An automated push notification sent in error by KFC Germany conflated the notorious 1938 pogrom and “tender cheese with crispy chicken.”

results.title: Two Big County Tallies in Nevada Show Democratic Route to Senate
results.abstract: The path became clearer on Wednesday night as the first post-election vote tallies in Nevada and Arizona showed Democrats faring well among mail voters.

media.caption: Senator Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada carried the first round of mail ballots in Clark County and Washoe County by two to one.

results.title: Tina Kotek, a Progressive, Will Be Oregon’s Next Governor
results.abstract: She will also be one of two of the nation’s first openly lesbian governors.

results.title: New Endorsements for College Athletes Resurface an Old Concern: Sex Sells
results.abstract: Female college athletes are making millions thanks to their large social media followings. But some who have fought for equity in women’s sports worry that their brand building is regressive.

media.caption: Olivia Dunne, a gymnast at Louisiana State, earns over $1 million annually in endorsements. “That is something I’m proud of,” she said, adding that most female athletes will not advance to a pro league after college.
media.copyright: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
